Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 10:53AM Anxiousmama wrote: (((hugs))) I 'm still learning myself so I don't have many answers. I'm pretty sure they can't officially diagnose cancer without a biopsy of some sort, so while the lumps may be suspicious for cancer I'm surprised they've told you that it was cancer at this point. I'd think the difference is not in the mammogram, but in who is reading it. And, a second opinion, especially if the results are uncertain, is always a good idea.

Posts.Content: Anxiousmama wrote: Just curious. I was called in last Friday (May 29) with the results of my biopsy - malignant. Still waiting on additional testing to make the decisions about surgery and treatment - MRI on Monday, CAT and PET scans the next Monday, had blood drawn for the BRCA test Tuesday. I'm a nervous wreck waiting but am trying to be patient b/c I want to have all the info to make the right decisions. But, have friends and relatives who keep asking when surgery is - I don't know and won't until the testing is back. Is this normal, or do most people go straight from diagnosis to surgery, then test later?  My tumor is 1.6 cm and slow growing, if this makes a difference.  How long was it between when your biopsy came back positive and you had surgery or started treatment? Posts.Content: Anxiousmama wrote: Does everyone else always get really nervous right before the oncologist appointment?  I have called in for most of my results and I expect him to go over those, discuss the options of radiation and chemo and most likely suggest radiation followed by tamoxifen, per my last conversation with his nurse. But for some reason I'm almost paralyzed with fear that I'm wrong or they've found something else they aren't telling me about. My mass was 2.5 cm, ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 5, Stage 2, and the oncotype test came back in the low intermediate range.  Appointment is in  1 1/2 hours and I have 3 pages of questions.    The rest of the time I can stay relatively calm and focus on what I need to do, but right before appointments I just go crazy. Anyone else do this? Stage 2A, ER/PR+, mama to two active boys Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: CT and PET scans Anxiousmama Aliceann

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 12:21PM Anxiousmama wrote: Hello, Just a couple of thoughts. I didn't have an MRI after surgery, just beforeit, so I'm not sure if the radiation oncologist will need it or not. I don't know why the book suggest getting the consult right after rx - some people end up not doing radiation if they have a full mastectomy.  Also, just wanted to point out that you may be going to radiation treatments daily for up to 7 weeks, so you may want to at least consider a place closer to home. With DCIS, if it is small enough, you might be able to do the mammosite treatment (my tumor was too large for that so it's not an option), so you may want to ask about that - that treatment lasts only a week or so I think.  My oncologist sent on any info the other dr's needed to have and I would think that if you told your onc who you are seeing they could take care of transferring info for you.   Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: questions for the radiation oncologist? tovahsmom newday1976

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 09:04PM Anxiousmama wrote: Hi. I'm having all of the above done. Had the MRI today, PET/CAT scan next week and the genetic testing is sent off. The way my oncologist and surgeon explained it all to me is that they would prefer to do surgery just once and all of these tests will help determine the best course of action and reduce the likelihood of having to do another surgery later. In my case, the genetic testing is b/c of my age. The genetic counselor I met with told me that it's fairly standard with women under about 50 who have breast cancer and that my insurance (and most in the U.S.) would cover it based on my age of getting breast cancer alone. A part of me would like them to just get in there, grab what they see and be done, but I don't want to have to have a second or even third surgery b/c they didn't know all the info going in so I"m trying to be patient.  HANG IN THERE!
Posts.Title: Is my doctor keeping something from me I should know? happytobealive happytobealive

Posts.Content: Anxiousmama wrote: Sorry, this isn't really a productive post at all, but I just have to complain b/c I had such a terrible experience getting my breast MRI today. I was rx'd just over a week ago. My core biopsy was done at the other branch of this same center so they should have all of my records, etc. The oncologist (not assoc. technically w/ this group and I love him), sent me there primarily b/c this location is close to my house (all others would be a 20-30 min. drive, most likely). I AM NOT GOING BACK THERE EVER. First, I get there and the lady at the front desk can't find my info, asks for my order from the dr. (which was faxed to them), gives me a hard time. I was about to just leave and call my oncologists office, but they suddenly figured it out.  Take me back and have me undress, put on the hospital gown and pants, take me to put my clothes in a locker, then sit me in a chair in the hall for 15 minutes. I fill out a bunch of paperwork, half of which I KNOW this office already has b/c I filled it out less than a month ago for my mammogram. Finally put in the IV thing, do the MRI.  All during the MRI, the guy keeps coming on the speaker thing asking why I'm having the MRI. BECAUSE I HAVE BREAST CANCER AND MY DOCTOR WANTS ADDITIONAL INFORMATION BEFORE SURGERY!!!! DUH!!!  Get out, he quizzes me again about any new symptoms, why are they doing it, etc. That's all in the paperwork.  Finally, he hands me the clipboard with my paperwork back, says "Here ya go. Take that back to the front desk." and walks off. What?!?!?! I was still in the hospital gown, etc. I put my shoes back on, pick up the key to the locker and flag down one of the workers rushing thru the hallway to show me to my locker. She points me in the right direction and walks off. I finally just lock myself in a random room, change and leave. I will not be going back to that place ever. It was awful! Stage 2A, ER/PR+, mama to two active boys Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI - just have to vent Anxiousmama awb

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 10:38AM Anxiousmama wrote: Thanks. I called my oncologist's nurse this morning and talked to her about it. She said that the idiot I dealt w/ was just the tech and that the radiologist would have ordered another MRI if the results were unclear. However, she agreed that they way I was treated was completely unacceptable and is reporting it. She also put a note in my chart not to send me there again and told me to remind the scheduler if there was a slipup. She said that they use that particular radiology group primarily b/c it is convenient for patients (it is), but any further testing that couldn't be done in the onc's office could be done at the nearby hospital with no problem at all. Feeling better about it today. Now to make it thru the CAT and PET scans next week and wait for the BRCA results. <sigh>

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 04:40PM Anxiousmama wrote: Well, I was supposed to start today but did not.  They had to redo my simulation b/c when the dr. came to look at the machine my other breast was getting in the way of the rays, so they moved me around and elevated me to prevent that.  I am feeling very frustrated with the dr.office, so wish me luck tomorrow. In addition to the above issue, they told me one time for the appointment but marked me down for a different time. I was told  9:30 and they wrote it on a card and gave it to me, but when I got there, the receptionist *insisted* that I was wrong and the appointment wasn't until 11:30 even when I showed her the card. She wouldn't let me go back until I burst into tears (b/c I had an appointment for my son elsewhere at 11:30 today) and people in the waiting room started watching what was happening she took me back to a room and I went out and found the dr's nurse to sort it out. I still don't know exactly why they changed the appointment time and didn't tell me, but they went ahead and saw me and redid the simulation. Now I just hope they told me the right time for tomorrow. <sigh>  I really am dreading dealing with this hateful woman for the next 7 weeks! Sue and fmakj:  I did not have chemo either. They said it would not be beneficial in my case - my numbers were almost identical to Sue's. My tumor was 2.6 cm., but there was no node involvement, oncotype dx score was also 18.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 12:08PM - edited Aug 14, 2009 12:44PM by Anxiousmama Hi everyone. I haven't posted in awhile. Just had #9 of 33 and so far so good. No redness to speak of. I've been using Curel cream for now - drr. said I could put any type of lotion I wanted so long as I did it more than 6 hours before treatment.  I have treatments in the a.m., so I put some on right after treatment and some just before bed. I'm very tired, but I don't know if that's the radiation or everything else in my life - car broke down Sunday, Air conditioner has been out all week (during a wave of 100+ highs) and kids are crazy with the last 2 weeks of summer vacation. I've been having to take my younger one with me this week and they've been very nice about it. Well, everyone but the mean receptionist. I heard her complaining to the nurse that I  had him there, so the next day the nurse caught me on my way in and said she was so sorry that they were no trouble and if I wanted they could come sit in a chair by her workstation while I was in the treatment room. =)  Ed. to add that I  am having some issues with my markings wearing off. I'm a little frustrated b/c they tattooed the dots so I wouldn't have to worry about it (we go out to the lake alot in the summer), but now also hhave to have a big X across my aerola which isn't tattooed, so I still have to worry about it. Any tips on keeping it "fresh"?  I swear it rubs off every day. Right now I'm at an inflatable playland while the kids play so I can just sit for awhile.  Good to hear most everyone is doing well. It may be another week before I find time to check in here.

Posts.Title: looking for reassurance lsdvn Anxiousmama

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 04:13AM Anxiousmama wrote: I was told by the radiological place that did my mammo (b/c I had left my referral paper in the car - then they realized it wasn't a screening and they did need the info from the dr) that you don't have to have a referral for a screening mammo, so you should be able to just set up an appointment and go. It is, however, unlikely that the insurance will pay for it. My insurance company does not pay for screening mammos for anyone under age 40, so I'd inquire about cost before making the appointment or going.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 08:47PM Anxiousmama wrote: hello all, I haven't checked in for awhile, but it was nice to see everyone's posts.  To everyone who is having nausea, I am also and I read in the pamplet I got from the onc that nausea is a common symptom for people who have radiation on the chest or abdomen, so I don't know why so many doctors are saying it is not. My radiation oncologist said that it's fairly common, but just try to eat foods that don't upset my stomach, etc.  I'm not having any redness, but some itching on my breast. Also a wierd sensation - when I scratch I can't really feel it on the skin but it hurts underneath.  Hard to describe but wondering if anyone else has that. I had no. 18 of 33  today and I'm getting soo tired of it all.  Not too much fatigue, but I've been taking better care of myself than I normally do. Sleeping more and not doing anything I don't really have to do.
